coredata.dc:title: Computerized segmentation and diagnostics of whole-body bone scintigrams

abstract.ce:para: Bone scintigraphy or whole-body bone scan is one of the most common diagnostic procedures in nuclear medicine. Since expert physicians evaluate images manually some automated procedure for pathology detection is desired. A robust knowledge based methodology for segmenting body scans into the main skeletal regions is presented. The algorithm is simultaneously applied on anterior and posterior whole-body bone scintigrams. Expert knowledge is represented as a set of parameterized rules, used to support standard image processing algorithms. The segmented bone regions are parameterized with algorithms for classifying patterns so the pathologies can be classified with machine learning algorithms. This approach enables automatic scintigraphy evaluation of pathological changes, thus in addition to detection of point-like high-uptake lesions also other types can be discovered. Our study includes 467 consecutive, non-selected scintigrams. Automatic analysis of whole-body bone scans using our segmentation algorithm gives more accurate and reliable results than previous studies. Preliminary experiments show that our expert system based on machine learning closely mimics the results of expert physicians. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency-matched-string: Slovenian Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Technology
xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Ministry of Education, Science and Technology

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This work was supported by the Slovenian Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Technology through the research programme P2-0209. Special thanks to nuclear medicine specialist Jure Fettich and the chief technologist Ivan Slodnjak at the University Medical Centre in Ljubljana, for their help. Luka Šajn was born on 24.10.1977 in Ljubljana, Slovenia. He is a researcher at the Faculty of Computer and Information Science in Ljubljana, Slovenia, where he finished his PhD studies. His research interests are: scintigraphy segmentation, pattern recognition and multiresolution pattern parameterization. Igor Kononenko is the professor at the Faculty of Computer and Information Science in Ljubljana. His research interests include artificial intelligence, machine learning, neural networks and cognitive modeling. Metka Milčinski is the professor at the Faculty of Medicine and works at the University Medical Centre in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Her research interests include different aspects of nuclear medicine imaging.

abstract.ce:para: Bone scintigraphy or whole-body bone scan is one of the most common diagnostic procedures in nuclear medicine. Since expert physicians evaluate images manually some automated procedure for pathology detection is desired. A robust knowledge based methodology for segmenting body scans into the main skeletal regions is presented.
